S3.T1.caption: TABLE I: Table of Notations for RSMA-based FEEL downlink System.

Parameters
𝒘nsuperscript𝒘𝑛\boldsymbol{w}^{n} Global model in n𝑛n-th communication round
𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} Local dataset collected at k𝑘k-th FV
disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} The i𝑖i-th part of training sample
𝒈knsubscriptsuperscript𝒈𝑛𝑘\boldsymbol{g}^{n}_{k} Local gradient estimate at k𝑘k-th FV in the n𝑛n-th round
η𝜂\eta Step size of the FEEL
B0subscript𝐵0B_{0} Data volume of the global model to be broadcast
M𝑀M Number of antennas in LV
Wk​(t)subscript𝑊𝑘𝑡W_{k}(t) Unicast message of k𝑘k-th vehicle at time t𝑡t
W0​(t)subscript𝑊0𝑡W_{0}(t) Broadcast message at time t𝑡t
sk​(t)subscript𝑠𝑘𝑡s_{k}(t) Private stream for k𝑘k-th vehicle at time t𝑡t
sc​(t)subscript𝑠𝑐𝑡s_{c}(t) Public stream at time t𝑡t
𝑳tr​(t)superscript𝑳tr𝑡\boldsymbol{L}^{\text{tr}}(t) Transmitted signal
𝑳re​(t)superscript𝑳re𝑡\boldsymbol{L}^{\text{re}}(t) Received signal
Ptsubscript𝑃𝑡P_{t} Transmit power of LV
𝒉k​(t)subscript𝒉𝑘𝑡\boldsymbol{h}_{k}(t) Fading channel vector between from LV to FV k𝑘k at time t𝑡t
nk​(t)subscript𝑛𝑘𝑡n_{k}(t) Circularly symmetric complex AWGN
γkp​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝛾𝑝𝑘𝑡\gamma^{p}_{k}(t) Instantaneous signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio of k𝑘k-th private message at time t𝑡t
γkc​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝛾𝑐𝑘𝑡\gamma^{c}_{k}(t) Instantaneous signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio of common message received by k𝑘k-th FV at time t𝑡t
B𝐵B Bandwidth of downlink channel
Rkp​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑝𝑘𝑡R^{p}_{k}(t) Achievable rate of transmitting unicast message Wk​(t)subscript𝑊𝑘𝑡W_{k}(t) via private stream sk​(t)subscript𝑠𝑘𝑡s_{k}(t) at time t𝑡t
Rkc​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑐𝑘𝑡R^{c}_{k}(t) Achievable rate for transmitting common message to k𝑘k-th FV at time t𝑡t
Rktot​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑅tot𝑘𝑡R^{\text{tot}}_{k}(t) Achievable rate of transmitting unicast message Wk​(t)subscript𝑊𝑘𝑡W_{k}(t) at time t𝑡t
Rkth​(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑅th𝑘𝑡R^{\text{th}}_{k}(t) Transmission rate requirement for sending control message to k𝑘k-th FV
𝒉~ksubscript~𝒉𝑘\tilde{\boldsymbol{h}}_{k} Estimate of channel vector
𝒉^ksubscript^𝒉𝑘\hat{\boldsymbol{h}}_{k} Corresponding channel estimation error
ΓksubscriptΓ𝑘\Gamma_{k} Average channel (power) gain
Γ~ksubscript~Γ𝑘\tilde{\Gamma}_{k} Estimated average channel (power) gain
Γ^ksubscript^Γ𝑘\hat{\Gamma}_{k} Corresponding estimation error of average channel (power) gain
ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon Motion coefficient for estimated average channel (power) gain
dk​(t)subscript𝑑𝑘𝑡d_{k}(t) Distance between LV and k𝑘k-th FV
μ𝜇\mu Free space path loss factor
Qtsubscript𝑄𝑡Q_{t} and Qhsubscript𝑄ℎQ_{h} Weight factors
Optimization variables
𝑷𝑷\boldsymbol{P} Precoding matrix
Ck​(t)subscript𝐶𝑘𝑡C_{k}(t) Portion of Rc​(t)superscript𝑅𝑐𝑡R^{c}(t) for transmitting k𝑘k-th unicast message at time t𝑡t
C0​(t)subscript𝐶0𝑡C_{0}(t) Portion of Rc​(t)superscript𝑅𝑐𝑡R^{c}(t) for transmitting broadcast message at time t𝑡t
ψ​(t)𝜓𝑡\psi(t) A bit-mask that ψ​(t)=1𝜓𝑡1\psi(t)=1 means W0​(t)subscript𝑊0𝑡W_{0}(t) is added into common-super messages to transmit the FEEL model to FV; otherwise, ψ​(t)=0𝜓𝑡0\psi(t)=0
references: where μ𝜇\mu is the path loss exponent and dk​(t)subscript𝑑𝑘𝑡d_{k}(t) is the distance between the LV and the FV k𝑘k. Table I summarizes the parameters used in our system.

S3.T2.caption: TABLE II: Table of Notations for Platoon Control System.
S3.T2.table:
Parameters
t𝑡t Index set of time period
T𝑇T Total number of time slot
Δ​tΔ𝑡\Delta t Time slot
ζ𝜁\zeta Number of time steps in each horizon
K𝐾K Number of vehicles
k𝑘k Index of k𝑘k-th vehicle
𝒛ksubscript𝒛𝑘\boldsymbol{z}_{k} States of the k𝑘k-th vehicle
𝒛kRefsubscriptsuperscript𝒛Ref𝑘\boldsymbol{z}^{\text{Ref}}_{k} Reference states of the k𝑘k-th vehicle
𝒖ksubscript𝒖𝑘\boldsymbol{u}_{k} Control input of the k𝑘k-th vehicle
λlsuperscript𝜆𝑙\lambda^{l} Length of the vehicle
λwsuperscript𝜆𝑤\lambda^{w} Width of the vehicle
βksubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k} Side slip angle of the k𝑘k-th vehicle
lkfsubscriptsuperscript𝑙𝑓𝑘l^{f}_{k}, lkrsubscriptsuperscript𝑙𝑟𝑘l^{r}_{k} Distance from the front and rear axles of the k𝑘k-th vehicle
𝐑𝐎𝐑𝐎\mathbf{RO} Orthogonal rotation matrix
trsubscriptt𝑟\textbf{t}_{r} Translation vector
𝑨𝑨\boldsymbol{A} and 𝒃𝒃\boldsymbol{b} Representation of polytopic sets k𝑘k
𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} Polytopic representation of the vehicle
f𝑓f Representation of vehicular kinematic bicycle model
Qzsubscript𝑄𝑧Q_{z}, Qusubscript𝑄𝑢Q_{u}, and QΔ​tsubscript𝑄Δ𝑡Q_{\Delta t} Weight factors
Optimization variables
vksubscript𝑣𝑘v_{k} Velocity of the vehicle k𝑘k
aksubscript𝑎𝑘a_{k} Acceleration of the vehicle k𝑘k
ϕksubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘\phi_{k} Heading angle of the vehicle k𝑘k
δksubscript𝛿𝑘\delta_{k} Steering angle of the vehicle k𝑘k
xksuperscript𝑥𝑘x^{k} Longitudinal position of the vehicle k𝑘k
yksuperscript𝑦𝑘y^{k} Lateral position of the vehicle k𝑘k
references: where (⋅)Tsuperscript⋅𝑇(\cdot)^{T} represents the transpose of the matrix, while λlsuperscript𝜆𝑙\lambda^{l} is the length and λwsuperscript𝜆𝑤\lambda^{w} is the width of the vehicle. Since the area occupied by each vehicle in the system is modeled as a time-varying polytope, at each time step, motion planning is activated for preventing any intersection among the polytopic sets. Table II shows the parameters of the platoon control system.

references: Based on the road settings in S1, we study the vehicles’ states and actions generated by the three baselines. In this part, we assume that there is one LV and three FVs moving along the road. Fig. 3a shows the vehicles’ motion trajectories generated by NOUM-aided RSMA. As shown in the results, the IoV platoon can help the vehicles to avoid obstacles by reconfiguring the platoon into a single-lane pattern at the right lane. Furthermore, Figs. 3b-3e present the heading angle, velocity, acceleration, and steering angle of the vehicles. In particular, the vehicles perform the lane-change in a smooth manner. Similarly, by considering the same road settings in S1, we evaluate the other two baseline communication techniques in the proposed IoV platoon control system. We also compare the mean and variance of the heading angle, velocity, acceleration, and steering angle of the vehicles. Table III presents the related results of characterizing both NOUM-aided MU-LP and unicast NOMA for the V2V communication module. Here, ΥΥ\Upsilon denotes the difference between the variance of the RSMA and MU-LP/NOMA in percentage, which is given by:

Variance 0.0008 0.0030 0.0409 0.0009
ΥΥ\Upsilon 0.0004 0.0022 0.0332 0.0003
references: In Fig 7, we further investigate the effect of the proposed IoV platoon system under different road conditions. Explicitly, Fig 7 shows the vehicles’ states and control inputs: (a) motion trajectories, (b) heading angle, (c) velocity, (d) acceleration, (e) steering angle, and (f) sum rate. Since the platoon system has to follow the traffic regulations, all the vehicles shall enter the straight lane before moving into the solid line area. In this case, the system should obey some additional constraints, in order to smoothly reconfigure the current platoon into a single-lane platoon. Furthermore, compared to the traffic behavior shown in S1, it is more challenging to make safe and smooth lane changes for the crossroad scenario. Nevertheless, our simulation results demonstrate the efficiency of the proposed IoV platoon under different road conditions. Moreover, we also compare the mean and the variance of the heading angle, velocity, acceleration, and steering angle of the vehicles. Table IV shows the related results characterizing the NOUM-aided MU-LP and the unicast NOMA for the V2V communication module. Compared to S1, the vehicles dedicate more effort to steering control in S2, which leads to a higher vehicular heading and steering angle variance. In this case, the RSMA-aided IoV platoon control scheme can still outperform both baselines in terms of its variance. Hence, these results prove the superiority of the RSMA scheme, as well as the robustness of the proposed IoV platoon system.
